{{About|special needs students|extended school years for the general school population|Year-round school in the United States}} In the United States, '''Extended School Year''' ('''ESY''') services are designed to support a student with a [[disability]] as documented under the [[Individuals with Disabilities Education Act]] (IDEA) to maintain the academic, social/behavioral, communication, or other skills that they have learned as part of their [[Individualized Education Program]] (IEP) or [[Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act|Section 504]] accommodation plan. In order for a student to receive ESY services, the student must have evidenced substantial regression and recoupment issues during the previous IEP year and/or there is evidence of emerging skills which are often referred to as "breakthrough" skills. The focus of the services provided to the student as part of an ESY program are generally not upon learning new skills or "catching up" to grade level, but rather to provide practice to maintain previously acquired or learned skills. In some cases ESY is focused on continuing education for students whose rate of progress is insufficient to enable effective progress during the regular school year. If a student has received ESY services in previous years the student may not be eligible in future years as determinations for eligibility of ESY services are made annually by the IEP or 504 plan (which includes the parent and student of age 16 or older. NOTE: The mandatory age at which a student must be included varies by State but the Federal law states no later than age 16.)
;(a) General. # Under the re-authorization of IDEA, effective July 1, 2005, each public agency must ensure that extended school year services are available as necessary to provide [[Free Appropriate Public Education]] (FAPE), consistent with paragraph (a)(2). # Extended school year services must be provided only if a child's IEP Team determines, on an individual basis, in accordance with Sec. Sec. 300.320 through 300.324, that the services are necessary for the provision of FAPE to the child. # In implementing the requirements of this section, a public agency may not— ## Limit extended school year services to particular categories of disability; or ## Unilaterally limit the type, amount, or duration of those services.
;(b) Definition. As used in this section, the term extended school year services means special education and related services that-- # Are provided to a child with a disability— ## Beyond the normal school year of the public agency; ## In accordance with the child's IEP; and ## At no cost to the parents of the child; and # Meet the standards of the [[State education agency]] (SEA).
(Authority: 20 U.S.C. 1412(a)(1))
==References== * http://idea.ed.gov/explore/view/p/,root,regs,300,B,300%252E106,
[[Category:Special education]] [[Category:United States federal education legislation]]

'''Fire history''', the ecological science of the study of the history of wildfires, is a subdiscipline of [[fire ecology]]. Patterns of forest fires in historical and prehistorical time provide information relevant to the pattern of vegetation in modern landscapes. It provides an estimate of the historical range of variability of a natural disturbance regime, and can be used to identify the processes affecting the occurrence of fire. Fire history reconstructions are achieved by compiling atlases of past fires, using the [[tree ring]] record from fire scars and tree ages, and the charcoal record from soils and sediments.
== Prehistoric fires == Sustained wildfire can only exist once oxygen levels and fuel sources were present in sufficient quantities. Between 400 and 450 million year ago, fire became a feature of the landscape.<ref name="Pyne2001">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/757509384|title=Fire : a brief history|last=1949-|first=Pyne, Stephen J.,|date=2001|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=029598144X|location=Seattle|oclc=757509384}}</ref>{{rp|11–14}} The presence of [[fusain]] (fossil charcoal), beginning in the early [[Carboniferous]] attests to this fire history and forms an important element of the [[Cretaceous–Paleogene boundary]].<ref name="Pyne2001" />{{rp|11–14}}<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2000-12-01|title=The Pre-Quaternary history of fire|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031018200001929|journal=Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology|volume=164|issue=1-4|pages=281–329|doi=10.1016/S0031-0182(00)00192-9|issn=0031-0182}}</ref>
==Mapped data== {{See also|Fire regime#Mapping fire regimes}} {{empty-section|date=January 2018}}
==Tree-ring data== {{refimprove section|date=January 2018}} [[File:PiceaAbiesWoodsample.jpg|thumb|241x241px|Tree core sample collected with an increment boarer]] [[File:Fire scarred Ponderosa pine (7204159758).jpg|thumb|241x241px|A cat-face fire scar on a [[ponderosa pine]]]] [[File:Fire scars in Pinus ponderosa crosscut.jpg|thumb|241x241px|A cross section of a ponderosa pine fire scar showing several dated fire events]] The growth record of a tree in seasonal climates is preserved in the growth rings in the stem wood; the field of [[dendrochronology]] is the study of the record of climate and other events preserved in the growth record. Each growth ring represents one year of life. The thickness of each ring indicates the amount of wood produced during that growing season. At the beginning of the growing season large cells are able to quickly divide creating a light colored wood. When growth slows down, generally in colder months, a darker wood is created from smaller cells dividing more slowly. Thus, one year is represented by a light inner ring and a darker outer ring.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theforestacademy.com/tree-knowledge/annual-growth-rings/#.Whs6c0qnFhF|title=Annual growth rings {{!}} Tree knowledge {{!}} Booklet {{!}} Forest Academy - Domtar|website=www.theforestacademy.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-26}}</ref>
Rings can be counted from dead trees as well as stumps left behind from logging. A sample can be collected from a living tree using tools like the [[increment borer]]. The increment borer is a hollow steel tube used to extract a core sample from a tree’s trunk. The growth rings in a core sample are counted to determine the age of that tree. Ages of stand-replacing fires may be determined by determining the cohort-age of trees that established after a fire. For example, tree-ring dating of large stands will show the age of the forest, and may provide an estimate of when the last large disturbance event occurred.
Sometimes growth rings exhibit scars. A fire scar forms when heat kills the vascular cambium beneath the bark, which then heals over subsequent years as growth rings curl over the scarred area, thus protecting the tree from infection.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fs.fed.us/rmrs/science-spotlights/making-scar-how-fire-scars-develop-trees|title=The making of a scar: How fire scars develop in trees {{!}} Rocky Mountain Research Station|website=www.fs.fed.us|language=en|access-date=2017-11-26}}</ref> This method can be used to date the year a fire occurred. Observing the scars establishes the timeline of a forest fire and the time between fires at a site. Surveying many trees over a large sample area provides a view to individual fire events and the overall fire regime. Not all tree species scar and show evidence of fire. Most pine species in the subgenus [[List of Pinus species#Subgenus Pinus|Pinus]] readily produce scars that are protected by resin; such scarring on other trees may result in death, leaving no fire record behind.
===Research and data examples=== Prior to Euro-American settlement in western North America, fire histories from scars preserved in ponderosa pine forests often reveal a pattern of frequent fire (often with 5 to 20 year intervals in a single area), with a pattern in time and space strongly related to past variations in climate.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Falk|first=Donald A|last2=Heyerdahl|first2=Emily K|last3=Brown|first3=Peter M|last4=Farris|first4=Calvin|last5=Fulé|first5=Peter Z|last6=McKenzie|first6=Donald|last7=Swetnam|first7=Thomas W|last8=Taylor|first8=Alan H|last9=Van Horne|first9=Megan L|date=2011-10-01|title=Multi-scale controls of historical forest-fire regimes: new insights from fire-scar networks|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1890/100052/abstract|journal=Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment|language=en|volume=9|issue=8|pages=446–454|doi=10.1890/100052|issn=1540-9309}}</ref> Fuel reduction from grazing and fire suppression greatly reduced the amount of fire in dry forests over the last 100 years.
A study by Arne Buechiling and William L. Baker in 2004 identified 41 fire events beginning in 1533 in a 9200-ha study area north of Estes Park, Colorado. They sampled 3461 tree cores and 212 fire scars.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Buechling|first=Arne|last2=Baker|first2=William L.|date=2004|title=A fire history from tree rings in a high-elevation forest of Rocky Mountain National Park|url=http://cjfr.nrc.ca/|journal=Canadian Journal of Forest Research|volume=34|pages=1259–1273|via=}}</ref> Fire scar data provided greater insight into the fire event parameters. Of the 41 fires, 22 where high-severity crown fires, 7 low-severity surface fires, and 8 mixed-severity fires. Fires larger than 300 ha were few, but composed a substantial proportion of the area burned since 1700. Drought periods led to larger fires.
There is little known about the fire history in some places. Central Europe for instance has a lack of intact forests with old growth trees or an abundance of dead or cut down trees that can be used to reconstruct the past fire regimes. An exception to this lacking history is the [[Białowieża Forest|Bialowieza Primeval Forest]] in Poland.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Niklasson|first=Mats|last2=Zin|first2=Ewa|last3=Zielonka|first3=Tomasz|last4=Feijen|first4=Markus|last5=Korczyk|first5=Adolf F.|last6=Churski|first6=Marcin|last7=Samojlik|first7=Tomasz|last8=Jedrzejewska|first8=Bogumiła|last9=Gutowski|first9=Jerzy M.|date=2010|title=A 350-year tree-ring fire record from Białowie_za Primeval Forest, Poland: implications for Central European lowland fire history|url=|journal=Journal of Ecology|volume=98|pages=1319–1329|via=}}</ref> A group of researchers were able to use a 350-year tree-ring fire record to reconstruct the fire history in precise detail. This is a shining example of how the method can be used in a place with lost or no written history of a fire regime.
== See also == * [[Fire ecology]] * [[Pyrogeography]] * [[Fossil record of fire]]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Ecological succession]] [[Category:Fire]] [[Category:Landscape ecology]]

The '''five-planet Nice model''' is a recent variation of the [[Nice model]] that begins with five [[giant planet]]s, the current four plus an additional [[ice giant]], in a chain of mean-motion resonances. After the [[orbital resonance|resonance]] chain is broken, the five giant planets undergo a period of planetesimal-driven migration, followed by a gravitational instability similar to that in the original Nice model. During the instability the additional giant planet is scattered inward onto a Jupiter-crossing orbit and is ejected from the [[Solar System]] following an encounter with Jupiter. An [[Formation and evolution of the Solar System|early Solar System]] with five giant planets was proposed in 2011 after numerical models indicated that this is more likely to reproduce the current Solar System.<ref name=Nesvorny_2011>{{cite journal|last=Nesvorný|first=David|title=Young Solar System's Fifth Giant Planet?|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2011|volume=742|issue=2|pages=L22|doi=10.1088/2041-8205/742/2/L22|arxiv = 1109.2949 |bibcode = 2011ApJ...742L..22N }}</ref>
==A five-planet Nice model==
The following is a version of the five-planet Nice model that results in a late instability and reproduces a number of aspects of the current Solar System. The early Solar System may have evolved differently, however, with the instability occurring [[Five-planet Nice model#Timing of the instability|soon after]] the dissipation of the gas nebula,<ref name="Kaib_Chambers_2016" /> or with the giant planets [[Five-planet Nice model#Initial conditions|beginning]] in another resonance chain.<ref name="Deienno_etal_2017" />
The Solar System ends its [[nebular hypothesis|nebula phase]] with [[Jupiter]], [[Saturn]], and the three ice giants in a 3:2, 3:2, 2:1, 3:2 resonance chain with [[semi-major axis|semi-major axes]] ranging from 5.5 – 20 [[astronomical unit|AU]]. A dense disk of [[planetesimal]]s orbits beyond these [[planet]]s, extending from 24 AU to 30 AU. [[impact event|Collisions]] between planetesimals in the outer disk produce debris that is ground to dust in a cascade of collisions. The dust spirals inward toward the planets due to [[Poynting–Robertson effect|Poynting-Robertson drag]] and eventually reaches [[Neptune]]'s orbit. Gravitational interactions with the dust allow the giant planets to escape from the resonance chain roughly ten million years after the dissipation of the [[Circumstellar disc|gas disk]]. After a series of distant planetary encounters the planets settle into an extended period of slow dust-driven migration.<ref name="Deienno_etal_2017" /> Their orbits slowly diverge over four hundred million years,<ref name="Bottke_2012" /> until Neptune approaches the inner edge of the planetesimal disk.<ref name="Deienno_etal_2017" />
The migration of the planets then accelerates and transitions to a [[Planetary migration#Planetesimal-driven migration|planetesimal-driven migration]] as Neptune encounters and exchanges [[angular momentum]] with an increasing number of planetesimals.<ref name="Deienno_etal_2017" /> A net inward transfer of planetesimals and outward migration of Neptune occur during these encounters as most of those [[gravity assist|scattered]] outward return to be encountered again while some of those scattered inward are prevented from returning after encountering [[Uranus]]. A similar process occurs for Uranus, the extra ice giant, and Saturn resulting in their outward migration and a transfer of planetesimals inward from the outer belt to Jupiter. Jupiter, in contrast, ejects most of the planetesimals from the Solar System, and as a result migrates inward.<ref name="Tsiganis_etal_2005" /> After 10 million years the divergent migration of the planets leads to resonance crossings, exciting the [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricities]] of the giant planets and destabilizing the planetary system when Neptune is near 28 AU.<ref name="Nesvorny_2015-a" />
During this instability the extra ice giant enters a Saturn-crossing orbit and is scattered inward by Saturn onto a Jupiter-crossing orbit. Repeated gravitational encounters with the ice giant cause jumps in Jupiter's and Saturn's semi-major axes, driving a step-wise separation of their orbits, leading to a rapid increase of the ratio of their [[orbital period|period]]s until it is greater than 2.3.<ref name="Brasser_etal_2009" /> The ice giant also encounters Uranus and Neptune and crosses parts of the [[asteroid belt]] as these encounters increase the eccentricity and semi-major axis of its orbit.<ref name="Roig_Nesvorny_2015" /> After 10,000–100,000 years,<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2010" /> the ice giant is ejected from the Solar System following an encounter with Jupiter, becoming a [[rogue planet]].<ref name="Nesvorny_2011" /> The remaining planets then continue to migrate at a declining rate and slowly approach their final orbits as most of the remaining planetesimal disk is removed.<ref name="Nesvorny_etal_2016" />
==Solar System effects== {{main article|Jumping-Jupiter scenario#Implications for the early Solar System}}
The migrations of the giant planets and encounters between them have many effects throughout the Solar System. The gravitational encounters between the giant planets excite their [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricities]] and [[orbital inclination|inclinations]].<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2009" /> The planetesimals scattered inward by Neptune enter planet-crossing orbits, initiating the [[Late Heavy Bombardment]].<ref name="Gomes_etal_2005" /> Impacts of these planetesimals leave [[impact crater|craters]] and impact basins on the [[natural satellite|moons]] of the [[outer planet]]s,<ref name="Rivera-Valentin_etal_2014">{{cite journal|last1=Rivera-Valentin|first1=E. G.|last2=Barr|first2=A. C.|last3=Lopez Garcia|first3=E. J.|last4=Kirchoff|first4=M. R.|last5=Schenk|first5=P. M.|title=Constraints on Planetesimal Disk Mass from the Cratering Record and Equatorial Ridge on Iapetus|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2014|volume=792|issue=2|page=127|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/792/2/127|arxiv=1406.6919|bibcode = 2014ApJ...792..127R }}</ref> and may result in the disruption of their inner moons.<ref name="Movshovitz_etal_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Movshovitz|first1=N.|last2=Nimmo|first2=F.|last3=Korycansky|first3=D. G.|last4=Asphaug|first4=E.|last5=Owen|first5=J. M.|title=Disruption and reaccretion of midsized moons during an outer solar system Late Heavy Bombardment|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|date=2015|volume=42|issue=2|pages=256–263|doi=10.1002/2014GL062133|bibcode = 2015GeoRL..42..256M }}</ref> Some of those planetesimals with semi-major axes similar to Jupiter's new semi-major axis are [[Jumping-Jupiter scenario#Jupiter trojans|jump-captured]] as [[Jupiter trojan]]s when Jupiter's semi-major axis jumps during encounters with the ejected ice giant. One group of Jupiter trojans can be depleted relative to the other if the ice giant passes through it following the ice giant's last encounter with Jupiter. Later, when Jupiter and Saturn are near mean-motion resonances, other Jupiter trojans can be captured via the mechanism described in the original [[Nice model#Trojans and the asteroid belt|Nice model]].<ref name=Nesvorny_2013>{{cite journal|last=Nesvorný|first=David|author2=Vokrouhlický, David |author3=Morbidelli, Alessandro |title=Capture of Trojans by Jumping Jupiter|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2013|volume=768|issue=1|page=45|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/768/1/45|arxiv=1303.2900|bibcode=2013ApJ...768...45N}}</ref><ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2005" /> Other planetesimals are captured as [[irregular satellite]]s of the giant planets via three-body interactions during encounters between the ejected ice giant and the other planets. The irregular satellites begin with wide range of inclinations including prograde, [[Retrograde and prograde motion|retrograde]], and perpendicular orbits.<ref name=Nesvorny_etal_2014>{{cite journal|last=Nesvorný|first=David|author2=Vokrouhlický, David |author3=Deienno, Rogerio |title=Capture of Irregular Satellites at Jupiter|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=784|issue=1|page=22|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/784/1/22|arxiv=1401.0253|bibcode=2014ApJ...784...22N|year=2014}}</ref> The population is later reduced as those in perpendicular orbits are lost due to the [[Kozai mechanism]],<ref name="Nesvorny_etal_2007" /> and others are broken up by collisions among them.<ref name="Botttke_etal_2010">{{cite journal|last1=Bottke|first1=William F.|last2=Nesvorný|first2=David|last3=Vokrouhlický|first3=David|last4=Morbidelli|first4=Alessandro|title=The Irregular Satellites: The Most Collisionally Evolved Populations in the Solar System|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2010|volume=139|issue=3|pages=994–1014|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/139/3/994|bibcode=2010AJ....139..994B|citeseerx=10.1.1.693.4810}}</ref> The encounters between planets can also [[perturbation (astronomy)|perturb]] the orbits of the regular satellites and may be responsible for the inclination of [[Iapetus (moon)|Iapetus]]'s orbit.<ref name=Nesvorny_2014>{{cite journal|last1=Nesvorný|first1=David|last2=Vokrouhlický|first2=David|last3=Deienno|first3=Rogerio|last4=Walsh|first4=Kevin J.|title=Excitation of the Orbital Inclination of Iapetus during Planetary Encounters|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2014|volume=148|issue=3|page=52|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/148/3/52|bibcode=2014AJ....148...52N|arxiv = 1406.3600 }}</ref> Saturn's rotational axis may have been tilted when it slowly crosses a [[secular resonance|spin-orbit resonance]] with Neptune.<ref name=Vokrouhlicky_Nesvorny_2015>{{cite journal|last1=Vokrouhlický|first1=David|last2=Nesvorný|first2=David|title=Tilting Jupiter (a bit) and Saturn (a lot) during Planetary Migration|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2015|volume=806|issue=1|page=143|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/806/1/143|arxiv=1505.02938|bibcode = 2015ApJ...806..143V }}</ref><ref name=Brasser_Lee_2015>{{cite journal|last1=Brasser|first1=R.|last2=Lee|first2=Man Hoi|title=Tilting Saturn without Tilting Jupiter: Constraints on Giant Planet Migration|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2015|volume=150|issue=5|page=157|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/150/5/157|arxiv=1509.06834|bibcode = 2015AJ....150..157B }}</ref>
While Neptune migrates outward several AU, the [[Kuiper belt#Classical belt|hot classical]] [[Kuiper belt]] and the [[scattered disk]] are formed as some planetesimals scattered outward by Neptune are captured in resonances, undergo an exchange of eccentricity vs inclination via the [[Kozai mechanism]], and are released onto higher [[perihelion and aphelion|perihelion]], stable orbits.<ref name=Nesvorny_2015-a>{{cite journal|last1=Nesvorný|first1=David|title=Evidence for Slow Migration of Neptune from the Inclination Distribution of Kuiper Belt Objects|journal=The Astronomical Journal|volume=150|issue=3|page=73|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/150/3/73|bibcode=2015AJ....150...73N|arxiv = 1504.06021 |year=2015}}</ref><ref name="Nesvorny_etal_2017" /> Planetesimals captured in Neptune's sweeping 2:1 resonance during this early migration are released when an encounter with the ice giant causes its semi-major axis to jump outward, leaving behind a group of low-inclination, low-eccentricity objects with semi-major axes near 44 AU.<ref name="Nesvorny_2015-b" /> This process avoids close encounters with Neptune allowing loosely bound [[binary asteroid|binaries]], including 'blue' binaries, to survive.<ref name="Fraser_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Fraser|first1=Wesley, C|last2=etal|title=All planetesimals born near the Kuiper belt formed as binaries|journal=Nature Astronomy|date=2017|volume=1|issue=4|page=0088|doi=10.1038/s41550-017-0088|arxiv=1705.00683 |bibcode = 2017NatAs...1E..88F }}</ref> An excess of low-inclination [[plutino]]s is avoided due to a similar release of objects from Neptune's 3:2 resonance during this encounter.<ref name=Nesvorny_2015-b>{{cite journal|last1=Nesvorný|first1=David|title=Jumping Neptune Can Explain the Kuiper Belt Kernel|journal=The Astronomical Journal|volume=150|issue=3|page=68|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/150/3/68|bibcode=2015AJ....150...68N|arxiv = 1506.06019 |year=2015}}</ref> Neptune's modest eccentricity following the encounter,<ref name="Wolff_etal_2012">{{cite journal|last1=Wolff|first1=Schuyler|last2=Dawson|first2=Rebekah I.|last3=Murray-Clay|first3=Ruth A.|title=Neptune on Tiptoes: Dynamical Histories that Preserve the Cold Classical Kuiper Belt|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2012|volume=746|issue=2|page=171|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/746/2/171|arxiv=1112.1954|bibcode=2012ApJ...746..171W}}</ref> or the rapid [[Precession#Astronomy|precession]] of its orbit,<ref name="Dawson_Murray-Clay_2012">{{cite journal|last1=Dawson|first1=Rebekah I.|last2=Murray-Clay|first2=Ruth|title=Neptune's Wild Days: Constraints from the Eccentricity Distribution of the Classical Kuiper Belt|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2012|volume=750|issue=1|page=43|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/750/1/43|arxiv=1202.6060|bibcode=2012ApJ...750...43D}}</ref> allows the primordial disk of [[Kuiper belt#Classical belt|cold classical]] Kuiper belt objects to survive.<ref name="Batygin_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Batygin|first1=Konstantin|last2=Brown|first2=Michael E.|last3=Fraser|first3=Wesley|title=Retention of a Primordial Cold Classical Kuiper Belt in an Instability-Driven Model of Solar System Formation|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2011|volume=738|issue=1|page=13|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/738/1/13|arxiv=1106.0937|bibcode=2011ApJ...738...13B}}</ref> If Neptune's migration is slow enough following this encounter the eccentricity distribution of these objects can be truncated by a sweeping mean-motion resonances.<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2014">{{cite journal|last1=Morbidelli|first1=A.|last2=Gaspar|first2=H. S.|last3=Nesvorny|first3=D.|title=Origin of the peculiar eccentricity distribution of the inner cold Kuiper belt|journal=Icarus|date=2014|volume=232|pages=81–87|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2013.12.023|arxiv=1312.7536|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103514000037|bibcode=2014Icar..232...81M}}</ref> As Neptune slowly approaches its current orbit, objects are left in fossilized high-perihelion orbits in the scattered disk.<ref name="Kaib_Sheppard_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Kaib|first1=Nathan A.|last2=Sheppard|first2=Scott S|title=Tracking Neptune's Migration History through High-Perihelion Resonant Trans-Neptunian Objects|date=2016|arxiv=1607.01777|doi=10.3847/0004-6256/152/5/133|volume=152|issue=5|journal=The Astronomical Journal|page=133|bibcode = 2016AJ....152..133K }}</ref><ref name="Nesvorny_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Nesvorny|first1=David|last2=Vokrouhlicky|first2=David|last3=Roig|first3=Fernando|title=The orbital distribution of trans-Neptunian objects beyond 50 au|date=2016|arxiv=1607.08279|doi=10.3847/2041-8205/827/2/L35|volume=827|issue=2|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|page=L35|bibcode = 2016ApJ...827L..35N }}</ref> Others with perihelia beyond Neptune's orbit but not high enough to avoid interactions with Neptune remain as a scattering objects,<ref name="Nesvorny_etal_2017" /> and those that remain in resonance at the end of Neptune's migration form the various [[resonant trans-Neptunian object|resonant populations]] beyond Neptune's orbit.<ref name="Nesvorny_Vokroulicky_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Nesvorný|first1=David|last2=Vokrouhlický|first2=David|title=Neptune's Orbital Migration Was Grainy, Not Smooth|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2016|volume=825|issue=2|page=94|doi=10.3847/0004-637X/825/2/94|arxiv=1602.06988|bibcode = 2016ApJ...825...94N }}</ref> Objects that are scattered to very large semi-major axis orbits can have their perihelia lifted beyond the influences of the giant planets by the galactic [[tidal force|tide]] or [[perturbation (astronomy)|perturbation]]s from passing [[star]]s, depositing them in the [[Oort cloud]]. If the hypothetical [[Planet Nine]] was in its proposed orbit at the time of the instability, objects would be captured in a cloud with semi-major axes centered on its semi-major axis.<ref name="Nesvorny_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Nesvorny|first1=D.|last2=Vokrouhlicky|first2=D.|last3=Dones|first3=L.|last4=Levison|first4=H. F.|last5=Kaib|first5=N.|last6=Morbidelli|first6=A.|title=Origin and Evolution of Short-Period Comets|arxiv=1706.07447|date=2017|doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa7cf6|volume=845|issue=1|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|page=27|bibcode = 2017ApJ...845...27N }}</ref>
In the inner Solar System, the rapid separation of the orbits of Jupiter and Saturn reduces the excitation of the eccentricities of the [[Solar System#Inner planets|inner planets]] due to [[secular resonance]] sweeping.<ref name=Brasser_2013>{{cite journal|last1=Brasser|first1=R.|last2=Walsh|first2=K. J.|last3=Nesvorny|first3=D.|title=Constraining the primordial orbits of the terrestrial planets|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2013|volume=433|issue=4|pages=3417–3427|doi=10.1093/mnras/stt986|arxiv=1306.0975|url=http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/433/4/3417|bibcode = 2013MNRAS.433.3417B }}</ref> Modest changes in the [[asteroid]]'s orbits also occur,<ref name=Roig_Nesvorny_2015>{{cite journal|last1=Roig|first1=Fernando|last2=Nesvorný|first2=David|title=The Evolution of Asteroids in the Jumping-Jupiter Migration Model|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2015|volume=150|issue=6|page=186|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/150/6/186|arxiv=1509.06105|bibcode = 2015AJ....150..186R }}</ref> potentially shifting the distribution of eccentricities from that of the [[grand tack hypothesis|Grand Tack]] model toward the current distribution.<ref name="Deienno_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Deienno|first1=Rogerio|last2=Gomes|first2=Rodney S.|last3=Walsh|first3=Kevin J.|last4=Morbidelli|first4=Allesandro|last5=Nesvorný|first5=David|title=Is the Grand Tack model compatible with the orbital distribution of main belt asteroids?|journal=Icarus|date=2016|volume=272|pages=114–124|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2016.02.043|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103516001214|bibcode=2016Icar..272..114D|arxiv = 1701.02775 }}</ref> Asteroid [[asteroid families|collisional families]] can be dispersed due to interactions with various resonances and by encounters with the ice giant as it crosses the asteroid belt.<ref name=Brasil_etal_2016>{{cite journal|last1=Brasil|first1=P. I. O.|last2=Roig|first2=F.|last3=Nesvorný|first3=D.|last4=Carruba|first4=V.|last5=Aljbaae|first5=S.|last6=Huaman|first6=M. E.|title=Dynamical dispersal of primordial asteroid families|journal=Icarus|date=2016|volume=266|pages=142–151|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2015.11.015|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103515005254|bibcode = 2016Icar..266..142B }}</ref> Planetesimals from the outer belt are embedded in the asteroid belt as [[P-type asteroid|P-]] and [[D-type asteroid]]s when their [[perihelion and aphelion|aphelion]] are lowered below Jupiter's orbit while they are in a resonance or during encounters with the ice giant, with some reaching the [[List of minor-planet groups#The asteroid belt|inner asteroid belt]] due to encounters with the ice giant.<ref name="Vokrouhlicky_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Vokrouhlický|first1=David|last2=Bottke|first2=William F.|last3=Nesvorný|first3=David|title=Capture of Trans-Neptunian Planetesimals in the Main Asteroid Belt|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2016|volume=152|issue=2|page=39|doi=10.3847/0004-6256/152/2/39|bibcode = 2016AJ....152...39V }}</ref> Roughly half of the asteroids escape the core of the asteroid belt (less than in the [[Nice model#The Late Heavy Bombardment|original Nice model]])<ref name="Gomes_etal_2005" /> and an [[e-belt asteroids|inner extension]] of the asteroid belt is disrupted when the planets reach their present positions, leading to a smaller, but extended, [[Late Heavy Bombardment]] of the inner planets by rocky objects.<ref name=Bottke_2012>{{cite journal|last=Bottke|first=William F.|author2=Vokrouhlický, David |author3=Minton, David |author4=Nesvorný, David |author5=Morbidelli, Alessandro |author6=Brasser, Ramon |author7=Simonson, Bruce |author8= Levison, Harold F. |title=An Archaean heavy bombardment from a destabilized extension of the asteroid belt|journal=Nature|date=2012|volume=485|issue=7396|pages=78–81|doi=10.1038/nature10967|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v485/n7396/full/nature10967.html|bibcode = 2012Natur.485...78B |pmid=22535245}}</ref>
==Development of the Nice model==
===Four planet models=== Current theories of [[planetary formation]] do not allow for the [[accretion (astrophysics)|accretion]] of Uranus and Neptune in their present positions.<ref name="Levison_Stewart_2001">{{cite journal |last=Levison |first=Harold F. |last2=Stewart |first2=Glen R. |title=Remarks on Modeling the Formation of Uranus and Neptune |journal=[[Icarus (journal)|Icarus]] |date=2001 |volume=153 |issue=1 |pages=224–228 |doi=10.1006/icar.2001.6672 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103501966722 |bibcode=2001Icar..153..224L }}</ref> The [[protoplanetary disk]] was too diffuse and the time scales too long<ref name=Thommes_etal_2002>{{cite journal |last=Thommes |first=E. W. |author2=Duncan, M. J. |last3=Levison |first3=Harold F. |title=The Formation of Uranus and Neptune among Jupiter and Saturn |journal=The Astronomical Journal |date=2002 |volume=123 |issue=5 |pages=2862–2883 |doi=10.1086/339975 |arxiv=astro-ph/0111290 |bibcode=2002AJ....123.2862T }}</ref> for them to form via planetesimal accretion before the gas disk dissipated, and numerical models indicate that later accretion would be halted once Pluto-sized planetesimals formed.<ref name=Kenyon_2008>{{cite journal|last=Kenyon|first=Scott J.|author2=Bromley, Benjamin C.|title=Variations on Debris Disks: Icy Planet Formation at 30–150 AU for 1–3 Msolar Main-Sequence Stars|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series|date=2008|volume=179|issue=2|pages=451–483|doi=10.1086/591794|arxiv = 0807.1134 |bibcode = 2008ApJS..179..451K }}</ref> Although more recent models including [[pebble accretion]] allow for faster growth the inward [[planetary migration|migration]] of the planets due to interactions with the gas disk leave them in closer orbits.<ref name="Bitsch_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Bitsch|first1=Bertram|last2=Lanbrects|first2=Michel|last3=Johansen|first3=Anders|title=The growth of planets by pebble accretion in evolving protoplanetary discs|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2015|volume=582|page=A112|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201526463|arxiv=1507.05209|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2015/10/aa26463-15/aa26463-15.html|bibcode=2015A&A...582A.112B}}</ref>
It is now widely accepted that the Solar System was initially more compact and that the outer planets migrated outward to their current positions.<ref name="Levison_Morbidelli_2005">{{cite journal |last=Levison |first=Harold F. |last2=Morbidelli |first2=Alessandro |title=Interaction of planetesimals with the giant planets and the shaping of the trans-Neptunian belt |journal=Dynamics of Populations of Planetary Systems, Proceedings of IAU Colloquium #197 |date=2005 |pages=303–316 |doi=10.1017/S1743921304008798 |url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/full/2005dpps.conf..303L |bibcode=2005dpps.conf..303L |volume=2004}}</ref> The planetesimal-driven migration of the outer planets was first described in 1984 by Fernandez and Ip.<ref name=Fernandez_Ip_1984>{{cite journal |last=Fernandez |first=J. A. |last2=Ip |first2=W. H. |title=Some dynamical aspects of the accretion of Uranus and Neptune – The exchange of orbital angular momentum with planetesimals |journal=Icarus |date=1984 |volume=58 |issue=1 |pages=109–120 |doi=10.1016/0019-1035(84)90101-5 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0019103584901015 |bibcode=1984Icar...58..109F }}</ref> This process is driven by the exchange of angular momentum between the planets and planetesimals originating from an outer disk.<ref name="Levison_etal_2007">{{cite journal |last=Levison |first=Harold F. |author2=Morbidelli |first2=Alessandro |last3=Gomes |first3=Rodney S. |last4=Backman |first4=D. |title=Planet Migration in Planetesimal Disks |journal=Protostars and Planets V |date=2007 |series=B. Reipurth, D. Jewitt, and K. Keil (eds.), University of Arizona Press |pages=669–684 |url=http://www.uapress.arizona.edu/Books/bid1812.htm }}</ref> Early dynamical models assumed that this migration was smooth. In addition to reproducing the current positions of the outer planets,<ref name="Gomes_etal_2004">{{cite journal |last=Gomes |first=Rodney S. |last2=Morbidelli |first2=Alessandro |last3=Levison |first3=Harold F. |title=Planetary migration in a planetesimal disk: why did Neptune stop at 30 AU? |journal=Icarus |date=2004 |volume=170 |issue=2 |pages=492–507 |doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2004.03.011 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103504000971 |bibcode=2004Icar..170..492G }}</ref> these models offered explanations for: the populations of resonant objects in the Kuiper belt,<ref name=Hahn_Malhotra_1999>{{cite journal|last=Hahn|first=Joseph M.|author2=Malhotra, Renu|title=Orbital Evolution of Planets Embedded in a Planetesimal Disk|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=1999|volume=117|issue=6|pages=3041–3053|doi=10.1086/300891|arxiv = astro-ph/9902370 |bibcode = 1999AJ....117.3041H }}</ref> the eccentricity of [[Pluto]]'s orbit,<ref name=Malhotra_1995>{{cite journal|last=Malhotra|first=Renu|title=The Origin of Pluto's Orbit: Implications for the Solar System Beyond Neptune|journal=Astronomical Journal|date=1995|volume=110|page=420|doi=10.1086/117532|arxiv = astro-ph/9504036 |bibcode = 1995AJ....110..420M }}</ref> the inclinations of the hot classical Kuiper belt objects and the retention of a scattered disk,<ref name="Gomes_2003">{{cite journal |last=Gomes |first=Rodney S. |title=The origin of the Kuiper Belt high-inclination population |journal=Icarus |date=2003 |volume=161 |issue=2 |pages=404–418 |doi=10.1016/S0019-1035(02)00056-8 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103502000568 |bibcode=2003Icar..161..404G }}</ref> and the low mass of Kuiper belt and the location of its [[Kuiper belt#Kuiper cliff|outer edge]] near the 2:1 resonance with Neptune.<ref name="Levison_Morbidelli_2003">{{cite journal |last=Levison |first=Harold F. |last2=Morbidelli |first2=Alessandro |title=The formation of the Kuiper belt by the outward transport of bodies during Neptune's migration |journal=Nature |date=2003 |volume=426 |issue=6965 |pages=419–421 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v426/n6965/full/nature02120.html |bibcode=2003Natur.426..419L |doi=10.1038/nature02120 |pmid=14647375 }}</ref> However, these models failed to reproduce the eccentricities of the outer planets, leaving them with very small eccentricities at the end of the migration.<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2009">{{cite journal |last=Morbidelli |first=Alessandro |last2=Brasser |first2=Ramon |last3=Tsiganis |first3=Kleomenis |last4=Gomes |first4=Rodney S. |last5=Levison |first5=Harold F. |title=Constructing the secular architecture of the solar system. I. The giant planets |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |date=2009 |volume=507 |issue=2 |pages=1041–1052 |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/200912876 |arxiv=0909.1886|bibcode = 2009A&A...507.1041M }}</ref>
In the original Nice model Jupiter and Saturn's eccentricities are excited when they cross their 2:1 [[orbital resonance|resonance]], destabilizing the [[Solar System#Outer Solar System|outer Solar System]]. A series of gravitational encounters ensues during which Uranus and Neptune are scattered outward into the planetesimal disk. There they scatter a great number of planetesimals inward accelerating the migration of the planets. The scattering of planetesimals and the sweeping of resonances through the asteroid belt produce a bombardment of the inner planets. In addition to reproducing the positions and eccentricities of the outer planets,<ref name="Tsiganis_etal_2005">{{cite journal|last=Tsiganis |first=Kleomenis |last2=Gomes |first2=Rodney S. |last3=Morbidelli |first3=Alessandro |last4=Levison |first4=Harold F. |title=Origin of the orbital architecture of the giant planets of the Solar System |journal=Nature |date=2005 |volume=435 |issue=7041 |pages=459–461 |doi=10.1038/nature03539 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v435/n7041/full/nature03539.html |bibcode = 2005Natur.435..459T |pmid=15917800 }}</ref> the original Nice model provided for the origin of: the [[Nice model#Trojans and the asteroid belt|Jupiter trojan]]s,<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2005">{{cite journal |last=Morbidelli |first=Alessandro |last2=Levison |first2=Harold F. |last3=Tsiganis |first3=Kleomenis |last4=Gomes |first4=Rodney S. |title=Chaotic capture of Jupiter's Trojan asteroids in the early Solar System |journal=Nature |date=2005 |volume=435 |issue=7041 |pages=462–465 |doi=10.1038/nature03540 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v435/n7041/full/nature03540.html |bibcode=2005Natur.435..462M |pmid=15917801 }}</ref> and the [[Neptune trojan]]s;<ref name=Nesvorny_Vokrouhlicky_2009>{{cite journal|last=Nesvorný|first=David|author2=Vokrouhlický, David|title=Chaotic Capture of Neptune Trojans|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2009|volume=137|issue=6|pages=5003–5011|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/137/6/5003|url=http://iopscience.iop.org/1538-3881/137/6/5003/|bibcode = 2009AJ....137.5003N }}</ref> the [[Nice model#Outer-system satellites|irregular satellites]] of Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune;<ref name=Nesvorny_etal_2007>{{cite journal |last=Nesvorný |first=David |author2=Vokrouhlický |first2=David |last3=Morbidelli |first3=Alessandro |title=Capture of Irregular Satellites during Planetary Encounters |journal=The Astronomical Journal |date=2007 |volume=133 |issue=5 |pages=1962–1976 |doi=10.1086/512850 |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/1538-3881/133/5/1962/ |bibcode=2007AJ....133.1962N }}</ref> the various populations of [[Nice model#Formation of the Kuiper belt|trans-Neptunian objects]];<ref name="Levison_etal_2008">{{cite journal |last=Levison |first=Harold F. |last2=Morbidelli |first2=Alessandro |last3=Van Laerhoven |first3=Christa |last4=Gomes |first4=Rodney S. |last5=Tsiganis |first5=Kleomenis |title=Origin of the structure of the Kuiper belt during a dynamical instability in the orbits of Uranus and Neptune |journal=Icarus |date=2008 |volume=196 |issue=1 |pages=258–273 |doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2007.11.035 |arxiv=0712.0553 |bibcode=2008Icar..196..258L }}</ref> the magnitude of, and with the right initial conditions, the timing of the [[Nice model#The Late Heavy Bombardment|Late Heavy Bombardment]].<ref name="Gomes_etal_2005">{{cite journal |last=Gomes |first=Rodney S. |last2=Levison |first2=Harold F. |last3=Tsiganis |first3=Kleomenis |last4=Morbidelli |first4=Alessandro |title=Origin of the cataclysmic Late Heavy Bombardment period of the terrestrial planets |journal=Nature |date=2005 |volume=435 |issue=7041 |pages=466–469 |doi=10.1038/nature03676 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v435/n7041/full/nature03676.html |bibcode=2005Natur.435..466G |pmid=15917802 }}</ref>
However, sweeping [[secular resonance]]s would perturb the orbits of inner Solar System objects if Jupiter's migration was slow and smooth. The ν<sub>5</sub> secular resonance crosses the orbits of the [[terrestrial planet]]s exciting their eccentricities.<ref name=Agnor_Lin_2012>{{cite journal|last=Agnor|first=Craig B.|author2=Lin, D. N. C.|title=On the Migration of Jupiter and Saturn: Constraints from Linear Models of Secular Resonant Coupling with the Terrestrial Planets|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2012|volume=745|issue=2|page=143|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/745/2/143|arxiv = 1110.5042 |bibcode = 2012ApJ...745..143A }}</ref> While Jupiter and Saturn slowly approach their 2:1 resonance the eccentricity of [[Mars]] reaches values that can result in collisions between planets or in Mars being ejected from the Solar System. [[Jumping-Jupiter scenario#Resonant planetary orbits|Revised versions]] of the Nice model beginning with the planets in a chain of resonances avoid this slow approach to the 2:1 resonance. However, the eccentricities of [[Venus]] and [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]] are typically excited beyond their current values when the ν<sub>5</sub> secular resonance crosses their orbits.<ref name="Brasser_etal_2009">{{cite journal |last=Brasser |first=Ramon |last2=Morbidelli |first2=Alessandro |last3=Gomes |first3=Rodney S. |last4=Tsiganis |first4=Kleomenis |last5=Levison |first5=Harold F. |title=Constructing the secular architecture of the solar system II: the terrestrial planets |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |date=2009 |volume=504 |issue=2 |pages=1053–1065 |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/200912878 |arxiv=0909.1891 |bibcode=2009A&A...507.1053B }}</ref> The orbits of the asteroids are also significantly altered: the ν<sub>16</sub> secular resonance excites inclinations and the ν<sub>6</sub> secular resonance excites eccentricities removing low-inclination asteroids as they sweep across the asteroid belt. As a result, the surviving asteroid belt is left with a larger fraction of high inclination objects than is currently observed.<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2010">{{cite journal |last=Morbidelli |first=Alessandro |last2=Brasser |first2=Ramon |last3=Gomes |first3=Rodney S. |last4=Levison |first4=Harold F. |last5=Tsiganis |first5=Kleomenis |title=Evidence from the Asteroid Belt for a Violent Past Evolution of Jupiter's Orbit |journal=The Astronomical Journal |date=2010 |volume=140 |issue=5 |pages=1391–1401 |doi=10.1088/0004-6256/140/5/1391 |arxiv=1009.1521 |bibcode = 2010AJ....140.1391M }}</ref>
The orbits of the inner planets and the orbital distribution of the asteroid belt can be reproduced if Jupiter encounters one of the ice giants, accelerating its migration.<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2010" /> The slow resonance crossings that excite the eccentricities of Venus and Mercury and alter the [[Asteroid belt#Orbits|orbital distribution]] of the asteroids occur when Saturn's period was between 2.1 and 2.3 times that of Jupiter's. Theorists propose that these were avoided because the divergent migration of Jupiter and Saturn was dominated by planet–planet scattering at that time. Specifically, one of the ice giants was scattered inward onto a Jupiter-crossing orbit by a gravitational encounter with Saturn, after which it was scattered outward by a gravitational encounter with Jupiter.<ref name="Brasser_etal_2009" /> As a result, Jupiter's and Saturn's orbits rapidly diverged, accelerating the sweeping of the secular resonances. This evolution of the orbits of the giant planets, similar to processes described by [[exoplanet]] researchers, is referred to as the [[jumping-Jupiter scenario]].<ref name=Fasset_Minton_2013>{{cite journal|last=Fassett|first=Caleb I.|author2=Minton, David A.|title=Impact bombardment of the terrestrial planets and the early history of the Solar System|journal=Nature Geoscience|date=2013|volume=6|issue=7|pages=520–524|doi=10.1038/ngeo1841|url=http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/v6/n7/full/ngeo1841.html|bibcode = 2013NatGe...6..520F }}</ref>
===Ejected planet===
The encounters between the ice giant and Jupiter in the jumping-Jupiter scenario often lead to the ejection of the ice giant. For this ice giant to be retained its eccentricity must be damped by [[dynamical friction]] with the planetesimal disk, raising its perihelion beyond Saturn's orbit. The planetesimal disk masses typically used in the Nice model are often insufficient for this, leaving systems beginning with four giant planets with only three at the end of the instability. The ejection of the ice giant can be avoided if the disk mass is larger, but the separation of Jupiter and Saturn often grows too large and their eccentricities become too small as the larger disk is cleared. These problems led David Nesvorný of the [[Southwest Research Institute]] to propose that the Solar System began with five giant planets, with an additional Neptune-mass planet between Saturn and Uranus.<ref name=Nesvorny_2011 /> Using thousands of simulations with a variety of initial conditions he found that the simulations beginning with five giant planets were ten times more likely to reproduce the orbits of the outer planets.<ref name=Stuart_2011>{{cite web|last=Stuart|first=Colin|title=Was a giant planet ejected from our solar system?|url=http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/2011/nov/21/was-a-giant-planet-ejected-from-our-solar-system|publisher=Physics World|accessdate=16 January 2014|date=2011-11-21}}</ref> A follow-up study by David Nesvorný and Alessandro Morbidelli found that the required jump in the ratio of Jupiter's and Saturn's periods occurred and the orbits of the outer planets were reproduced in 5% of simulations for one five-planet system vs less than 1% for four-planet systems. The most successful began with a significant migration of Neptune, disrupting the planetesimal disk, before planetary encounters were triggered by resonance crossing. This reduces secular friction, allowing Jupiter's eccentricity to be preserved after it is excited by resonance crossings and planetary encounters.<ref name="Nesvorny_Morbidelli_2012">{{cite journal |last=Nesvorný |first=David |last2=Morbidelli |first2=Alessandro |title=Statistical Study of the Early Solar System's Instability with Four, Five, and Six Giant Planets |journal=The Astronomical Journal |date=2012 |volume=144 |issue=4 |page=17 |doi=10.1088/0004-6256/144/4/117 |arxiv=1208.2957 |bibcode=2012AJ....144..117N }}</ref>
[[Konstantin Batygin]], [[Michael E. Brown]], and Hayden Betts, in contrast, found four- and five-planet systems had a similar likelihoods (4% vs 3%) of reproducing the orbits of the outer planets, including the oscillations of Jupiter's and Saturn's eccentricities, and the hot and cold populations of Kuiper belt.<ref name="Batygin_etal_2011" /><ref name="Batygin_etal_2012" /> In their investigations Neptune's orbit was required to have a high eccentricity phase during which the hot population was implanted.<ref name=Batygin_2010>{{cite journal|last=Batygin|first=Konstantin|author2=Brown, Michael E.|title=Early Dynamical Evolution of the Solar System: Pinning Down the Initial Conditions of the Nice Model|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2010|volume=716|issue=2|pages=1323–1331|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/716/2/1323|arxiv=1004.5414|bibcode=2010ApJ...716.1323B}}</ref> A rapid precession of Neptune's orbit during this period due to interactions with Uranus was also necessary for the preservation a primordial belt of cold classical objects.<ref name="Batygin_etal_2011">{{cite journal|last1=Batygin|first1=Konstantin|last2=Brown|first2=Michael E.|last3=Fraser|first3=Wesly C.|title=Retention of a Primordial Cold Classical Kuiper Belt in an Instability-Driven Model of Solar System Formation|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2011|volume=738|issue=1|page=13|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/738/1/13|arxiv=1106.0937|bibcode=2011ApJ...738...13B}}</ref> For a five-planet system they found that the low eccentricities of the cold classical belt were best preserved if the fifth giant planet was ejected in 10,000 years.<ref name="Batygin_etal_2012">{{cite journal |last=Batygin |first=Konstantin |last2=Brown |first2=Michael E. |last3=Betts |first3=Hayden |title=Instability-driven Dynamical Evolution Model of a Primordially Five-planet Outer Solar System|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2012|volume=744|issue=1|page=L3|doi=10.1088/2041-8205/744/1/L3|arxiv = 1111.3682 |bibcode = 2012ApJ...744L...3B }}</ref> Since their study examined only the outer Solar System, it did not include a requirement that Jupiter's and Saturn's orbits diverged rapidly as would be necessary to reproduce the current inner Solar System, however.<ref name="Nesvorny_Morbidelli_2012" />
A number of previous works also modeled Solar Systems with extra giant planets. A study by Thommes, Bryden, Wu, and Rasio included simulations of four and five planets beginning in resonant chains. Loose resonant chains of four or five planets with Jupiter and Saturn beginning in a 2:1 resonance often resulted in the loss of an ice giant for small mass planetesimal disks. The loss of a planet was avoided in four planet systems with a larger planetesimal disk but no scattering of planets occurred. A more compact system with Jupiter and Saturn in a 3:2 resonance sometimes resulted in encounters occurring between Jupiter and Saturn.<ref name="Thommes_etal_2007">{{cite journal|last1=Thommes|first1=Edward W.|last2=Bryden|first2=Geoffrey|last3=Wu|first3=Yanqin|last4=Rasio|first4=Frederic A|title=From Mean Motion Resonances to Scattered Planets: Producing the Solar System, Eccentric Exoplanets, and Late Heavy Bombardments|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2007|volume=675|issue=2|pages=1538–1548|doi=10.1086/525244|arxiv=0706.1235|bibcode=2008ApJ...675.1538T}}</ref> A study by Morbidelli, Tsiganis, Crida, Levison, and Gomes was more successful in reproducing the Solar System beginning with a four planet system in a compact resonant chain. They also modeled the capture of planets in a five planet resonant chain and noted the planets had larger eccentricities and the system became unstable within 30 Myr.<ref name=Morbidelli_2007>{{cite journal|last=Morbidelli|first=Alessandro|author2=Tsiganis, Kleomenis |author3=Crida, Aurélien |author4=Levison, Harold F. |author5= Gomes, Rodney |title=Dynamics of the Giant Planets of the Solar System in the Gaseous Protoplanetary Disk and Their Relationship to the Current Orbital Architecture|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2007|volume=134|issue=5|pages=1790–1798|doi=10.1086/521705|arxiv=0706.1713|bibcode=2007AJ....134.1790M}}</ref> Ford and Chiang modeled systems of planets in a packed oligarcy, the result of their formation in a more massive dynamically cool disk. They found that the extra planets would be ejected as the density of the primordial disk declined.<ref name="Ford_Chiang_2007">{{cite journal|last1=Ford|first1=Eric B.|last2=Chiang|first2=Eugene I.|title=The Formation of Ice Giants in a Packed Oligarchy: Instability and Aftermath|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2007|volume=661|issue=1|pages=602–615|doi=10.1086/513598|arxiv=astro-ph/0701745|bibcode=2007ApJ...661..602F}}</ref> Simulations by Levison and Morbidelli, in contrast, showed that the planets in such systems would spread out rather than be ejected.<ref name="Levison_Morbidelli_2007">{{cite journal|last1=Levison|first1=Harold F.|last2=Morbidelli|first2=Alessandro|title=Models of the collisional damping scenario for ice-giant planets and Kuiper belt formation|journal=Icarus|date=2007|volume=189|issue=1|pages=196–212|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2007.01.004|arxiv=astro-ph/0701544|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103507000371|bibcode=2007Icar..189..196L}}</ref>
===Initial conditions===
The giant planets begin in a chain of resonances. During their formation in the protoplanetary disk, interactions between the giant planets and the gas disk caused them to migrate inward toward the Sun. Jupiter's inward migration continued until it was halted, or reversed, as in the [[Grand tack hypothesis|Grand Tack]] model, when it captured a faster migrating Saturn in a mean-motion resonance.<ref name=Masset_2001>{{cite journal|last=Masset|first=F.|author2=Snellgrove, M.|title=Reversing type II migration: resonance trapping of a lighter giant protoplanet|journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]]|date=2001|volume=320|issue=4|pages=L55–L59|doi=10.1046/j.1365-8711.2001.04159.x|arxiv=astro-ph/0003421|bibcode = 2001MNRAS.320L..55M }}</ref> The resonance chain was extended as the three ice giants also migrated inward and were captured in further resonances.<ref name="Nesvorny_Morbidelli_2012" /> A long-range migration of Neptune outward into the planetesimal disk before planetary encounters begins is most likely if the planets were captured in a 3:2, 3:2, 2:1, 3:2 resonance chain, occurring in 65% of simulations when the inner edge was within 2 [[Astronomical unit|AU]]. While this resonance chain has the highest likelihood of reproducing Neptune's migration other resonance chains are also possible if the instability occurred early.<ref name="Deienno_etal_2017" />
A late instability may have followed an extended period of slow dust-driven migration. The combination of a late escape from a resonance chain, as described in the [[Nice 2 model]], and a long-range migration of Neptune is unlikely. If the inner edge of the planetesimal disk is close an early escape from resonance occurs, if it is distant an instability typically triggered before a significant migration of Neptune occurs. This gap may be bridged if an early escape from resonance is followed by an extended period of slow dust-driven migration. Resonance chains other than the 3:2, 3:2, 2:1, 3:2 are unlikely in this case. Instabilities occur during the slow migration for tighter resonance chains and the distant disk is unrealistically narrow for more relaxed resonance chains. The rate of dust-driven migration slows with time as the rate of dust generation declines. As a result, the timing of the instability is sensitive to factors that determine the rate of dust generation such as the size distribution and the strength of the planetesimals.<ref name="Deienno_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Deienno|first1=Rogerio|last2=Morbidelli|first2=Alessandro|last3=Gomes|first3=Rodney S.|last4=Nesvorny|first4=David|title=Constraining the giant planets' initial configuration from their evolution: implications for the timing of the planetary instability|date=2017|arxiv=1702.02094|doi=10.3847/1538-3881/aa5eaa|volume=153|issue=4|journal=The Astronomical Journal|page=153|bibcode = 2017AJ....153..153D }}</ref>
===Timing of the instability===
The timing of the instability in the Nice model was initially proposed to have coincided with the Late Heavy Bombardment, a spike in the impact rate thought to have occurred several million years after the formation of the Solar System. However, recently a number of issues have been raised regarding the timing of the Nice model instability, whether it was the cause of the Late Heavy Bombardment, and if an alternative would better explain the associated craters and impact basins. Most of the effects of the Nice model instability on the orbits of the giant planets and those of the various small body populations from the asteroid belt outward to the scattered disk are independent of its timing, however.
A five-planet Nice model with a late instability has a low probability of reproducing the orbits of the terrestrial planets. Jupiter's and Saturn's period ratio makes the required jump in a small fraction of simulations (7%–8.7%)<ref name="Nesvorny_Morbidelli_2012" /><ref name=Kaib_Chambers_2016>{{cite journal|last1=Kaib|first1=Nathan A.|last2=Chambers|first2=John E.|title=The fragility of the terrestrial planets during a giant-planet instability|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2016|volume=455|issue=4|pages=3561–3569|doi=10.1093/mnras/stv2554|url=http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/455/4/3561|bibcode = 2016MNRAS.455.3561K |arxiv = 1510.08448}}</ref> and the eccentricities of the terrestrial planets can also be excited when Jupiter encounters the ice giant.<ref name="Agnor_Lin_2012" /> In a study by Nathan Kaib and John Chambers this resulted in the orbits of the terrestrial planets being reproduced in a few percent of simulation with only 1% reproducing both the terrestrial and giant planets orbits. This led Kaib and Chambers to propose that the instability occurred early, before the formation of the terrestrial planets.<ref name="Kaib_Chambers_2016" /> However, a jump in the ratio of the orbital periods of Jupiter and Saturn is still required to reproduce the asteroid belt, reducing the advantage of an early instability.<ref name="Walsh_Morbidelli_2011">{{cite journal|last1=Walsh|first1=K. J.|last2=Morbidelli|first2=A.|title=The effect of an early planetesimal-driven migration of the giant planets on terrestrial planet formation|journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics|date=2011|volume=526|page=A126|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201015277|arxiv=1101.3776|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2011/02/aa15277-10/aa15277-10.html|bibcode=2011A&A...526A.126W}}</ref><ref name="Toliou_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Toliou|first1=A.|last2=Morbidelli|first2=A.|last3=Tsiganis|first3=K.|title=Magnitude and timing of the giant planet instability: A reassessment from the perspective of the asteroid belt|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2016|volume=592|page=A72|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201628658|arxiv=1606.04330|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2016/08/aa28658-16/aa28658-16.html|bibcode=2016A&A...592A..72T}}</ref> A previous study by Ramon Brasser, Kevin Walsh, and David Nesvorny found a reasonable chance (greater than 20%) of reproducing the inner Solar System using a selected five-planet model.<ref name=Brasser_2013/> The shapes of the impact basins on Iapetus are also consistent with a late bombardment.<ref name="Robuchon_etal_2011">{{cite journal|last1=Robuchon|first1=Guillaume|last2=Nimmo|first2=Francis|last3=Roberts|first3=James|last4=Kirchoff|first4=Michelle|title=Impact basin relaxation at Iapetus|journal=Icarus|date=2011|volume=214|issue=1|pages=82–90|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2011.05.011|arxiv=1406.6919|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S001910351100176X|bibcode=2011Icar..214...82R}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rivera-Valentin|first1=E. G.|last2=Barr|first2=A. C.|last3=Lopez Garcia|first3=E. K.|last4=Kirchoff|first4=M. R.|last5=Schenk|first5=P. M.|title=Constraints on Planetesimal Disk Mass from the Cratering Record and Equatorial Ridge on Iapetus|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2014|volume=792|issue=2|page=127|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/792/2/127|bibcode=2014ApJ...792..127R|arxiv = 1406.6919 }}</ref>
Sufficient mass may not remain in the planetesimal disk after 400 million years of collisional grinding to fit models of the instability. If the size distribution of the planetesimal disk initially resembled its current distribution and included 1000's of Pluto mass objects significant mass loss occurs. This leaves the disk with under 10 Earth masses, while a minimum of 15 Earth masses is needed in current models of the instability. The size distribution also becomes shallower than is observed. These problems remain even if simulations begin with a more massive disk or a steeper size distribution. In contrast, a much lower mass loss and little change in the size distribution occurs during a early instability.<ref name="Nesvorny_etal_2018a">{{cite journal|last1=Nesvorny|first1=David|last2=Parker|first2=Joel|last3=Vokrouhlicky|first3=David|title=Bi-lobed Shape of Comet 67P from a Collapsed Binary|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2018|volume=155|issue=6|page=246|doi=10.3847/1538-3881/aac01f|arxiv=1804.08735|bibcode=2018AJ....155..246N}}</ref> If the planetesimal disk began without Pluto mass objects collisional grinding would begin as they formed from smaller object, with the timing depending on the initial size of the objects and mass of the planetesimal disk.<ref name="Kenyon_Bromley_2012">{{cite journal|last1=Kenyon|first1=Scott J.|last2=Bromley|first2=Benjamin C.|title=Coagulation Calculations of Icy Planet Formation at 15-150 AU: A Correlation between the Maximum Radius and the Slope of the Size Distribution for Trans-Neptunian Objects|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2012|volume=143|issue=3|page=63|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/143/3/63|arxiv=1201.4395|bibcode=2012AJ....143...63K}}</ref>
Binary objects such as [[617 Patroclus|Patroclus]]-Menoetius would be separated due to the collisions if the instability was late. Patroclus and Menoetius are a pair of ~100 km objects orbiting with a separation of 680 km and relative velocities of ~11 m/s. While this binary remains in a massive planetesimal disk it is vulnerable to being separated due to collision. Roughly ~90% of similar binaries are separated per hundred million years in simulations and after 400 million years its survival probabilities falls to 7 × 10<sup>-5</sup>. The presence of Patroclus-Menoetius among the Jupiter Trojans requires that the giant planet instability occurred within 100 million years of the formation of the Solar System.<ref name="Nesvorny_etal_2018b">{{cite journal |last1=Nesvorný |first1=David |last2=Vokrouhlický |first2=David |last3=Bottke |first3=William F. |last4=Levison |first4=Harold F. |title=Evidence for very early migration of the Solar System planets from the Patroclus–Menoetius binary Jupiter Trojan |journal=Nature Astronomy |volume=2 |issue=11 |pages=878–882 |date=2018 |doi=10.1038/s41550-018-0564-3 |arxiv=1809.04007 }}</ref>
The bombardment produced by the Nice model may not match the Late Heavy Bombardment. An impactor size distribution similar to the asteroids would result in too many large impact basins relative to smaller craters.<ref name="Minton_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Minton|first1=David A.|last2=Richardson|first2=James E.|last3=Fasset|first3=Caleb I.|title=Re-examining the main asteroid belt as the primary source of ancient lunar craters|journal=Icarus|date=2015|volume=247|pages=172–190|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2014.10.018|arxiv=1408.5304|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103514005570|bibcode=2015Icar..247..172M}}</ref> The [[e-belt asteroids|innermost]] asteroid belt would need a different size distribution, perhaps due to its small asteroids being the result of collisions between a small number of large asteroids, to match this constraint.<ref name="Bottke_etal_2015">{{cite web|last1=Bottke|first1=W. F.|last2=Marchi|first2=S.|last3=Vokrouhlicky|first3=D.|last4=Robbins|first4=S.|last5=Hynek|first5=B.|last6=Morbidelli|first6=A.|title=New Insights into the Martian Late Heavy Bombardment|url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2015/pdf/1484.pdf|publisher=46th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference}}</ref> While the Nice model predicts a bombardment by both asteroids and [[comet]]s,<ref name="Gomes_etal_2005" /> most evidence (although not all)<ref name="Grae Jorgensen_etal_2009">{{cite journal|last1=Gråe Jørgensen|first1=Uffe|last2=Appel|first2=Peter W. U.|last3=Hatsukawa|first3=Yuichi|last4=Frei|first4=Robert|last5=Oshima|first5=Masumi|last6=Toh|first6=Yosuke|last7=Kimura|first7=Atsushi|title=The Earth-Moon system during the late heavy bombardment period – Geochemical support for impacts dominated by comets|journal=Icarus|date=2009|volume=204|issue=2|pages=368–380|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2009.07.015|arxiv=0907.4104|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103509002905|bibcode=2009Icar..204..368G|citeseerx=10.1.1.312.7222}}</ref> points toward a bombardment dominated by asteroids.<ref name="Kring_Cohen_2002">{{cite journal|last1=Kring|first1=David A.|last2=Cohen|first2=Barbara A.|title=Cataclysmic bombardment throughout the inner solar system 3.9–4.0 Ga|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Planets|date=2002|volume=107|issue=E2|pages=4–1–4–6|doi=10.1029/2001JE001529|bibcode = 2002JGRE..107.5009K }}</ref><ref name="Joy_etal_2012">{{cite journal|last1=Joy|first1=Katherine H.|last2=Zolensky|first2=Michael E.|last3=Nagashima|first3=Kazuhide|last4=Huss|first4=Gary R.|last5=Ross|first5=D. Kent|last6=McKay|first6=David S.|last7=Kring|first7=David A.|title=Direct Detection of Projectile Relics from the End of the Lunar Basin-Forming Epoch|journal=Science|date=2012|volume=336|issue=6087|pages=1426–9|doi=10.1126/science.1219633|pmid=22604725|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/336/6087/1426.full|bibcode = 2012Sci...336.1426J }}</ref><ref name="Strom_etal_2005">{{cite journal|last1=Strom|first1=Robert G.|last2=Malhotra|first2=Renu|last3=Ito|first3=Takashi|last4=Yoshida|first4=Fumi|last5=Kring|first5=David A.|title=The Origin of Planetary Impactors in the Inner Solar System|journal=Science|date=2005|volume=309|issue=5742|pages=1847–1850|doi=10.1126/science.1113544|pmid=16166515|arxiv=astro-ph/0510200|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/309/5742/1847.full|bibcode = 2005Sci...309.1847S |citeseerx=10.1.1.317.2438}}</ref> This may reflect the reduced cometary bombardment in the five-planet Nice model and the significant mass loss or the break-up of comets after entering the inner Solar System,<ref name="Rickman_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Rickman|first1=H.|last2=Wiśniowsk|first2=T.|last3=Gabryszewski|first3=R.|last4=Wajer|first4=P.|last5=Wójcikowsk|first5=K.|last6=Szutowicz|first6=S.|last7=Valsecchi|first7=G. B.|last8=Morbidelli|first8=A.|title=Cometary impact rates on the Moon and planets during the late heavy bombardment|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2017|volume=598|page=A67|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201629376|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2017/02/aa29376-16/aa29376-16.html|bibcode=2017A&A...598A..67R}}</ref> potentially allowing the evidence of cometary bombardment to have been lost.<ref name="Bottke_2012_Supplement">{{cite journal|last=Bottke|first=William F.|author2=Vokrouhlický, David |author3=Minton, David |author4=Nesvorný, David |author5=Morbidelli, Alessandro |author6=Brasser, Ramon |author7=Simonson, Bruce |author8= Levison, Harold F. |title=An Archaean heavy bombardment from a destabilized extension of the asteroid belt: Supplementary Information|journal=Nature|year=2012|volume=485|issue=7396|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v485/n7396/extref/nature10967-s1.pdf}}</ref> However, two recent estimates of the asteroid bombardment find it is also insufficient to explain the Late Heavy Bombardment.<ref name="Johnson_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Johnson|first1=Brandon C.|last2=Collins|first2=Garath S.|last3=Minton|first3=David A.|last4=Bowling|first4=Timothy J.|last5=Simonson|first5=Bruce M.|last6=Zuber|first6=Maria T.|title=Spherule layers, crater scaling laws, and the population of ancient terrestrial impactors|journal=Icarus|date=2016|volume=271|pages=350–359|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2016.02.023|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103516000907|bibcode=2016Icar..271..350J|hdl=10044/1/29965}}</ref><ref name="Nesvorny_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Nesvorny|first1=David|last2=Roig|first2=Fernando|last3=Bottke|first3=William F.|title=Modeling the Historical Flux of Planetary Impactors|journal=The Astronomical Journal|date=2016|volume=153|issue=3|page=103|doi=10.3847/1538-3881/153/3/103|arxiv=1612.08771|bibcode = 2017AJ....153..103N }}</ref> Reproducing the lunar craters and impact basins identified with the Late Heavy Bombardment, about 1/6 of the craters larger than 150 km in diameter, and the craters on Mars may be possible if a different crater-scaling law is used. The remaining lunar craters would then be the result of another population of impactors with a different size distribution, possibly planetesimals left over from the formation of the planets.<ref name="Bottke_etal_2017">{{cite web|last1=Bottke|first1=W. F.|last2=Nesvorny|first2=D.|last3=Roig|first3=F.|last4=Marchi|first4=S.|last5=Vokrouhlicky|first5=D.|title=Evidence for Two Impacting Populations in the Early Bombardment of Mars and the Moon|url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2017/pdf/2572.pdf|publisher=48th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference}}</ref> This crater-scaling law also is more successful at reproducing the more recently formed large craters.<ref name="Bottke_etal_2016">{{cite web|last1=Bottke|first1=W. F.|last2=Vokrouhlicky|first2=D.|last3=Ghent|first3=B.|last4=Mazrouei|first4=S.|last5=Robbins|first5=S.|last6=marchi|first6=S.|title=On Asteroid Impacts, Crater Scaling Laws, and a Proposed Younger Surface Age for Venus|url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2036.pdf|publisher=47th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference}}</ref>
The craters and impact basins identified with the Late Heavy Bombardment may have another cause. Some recently offered alternatives include debris from the impact that formed the [[North Polar Basin (Mars)|Borealis Basin]] on Mars,<ref name="Minton 2015b">{{cite web|last1=Minton|first1=D. A.|last2=Jackson|first2=A. P.|last3=Asphaug|first3=E.|last4=Fasset|first4=C. I.|last5=Richardson|first5=J. E.|title=Debris from Borealis Basin Formation as the Primary Impactor Population of Late Heavy Bombardment|url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/bombardment2015/pdf/3033.pdf|publisher=Workshop on Early Solar System Impact Bombardment III}}</ref> and catastrophic collisions among lost planets once orbiting inside Mercury.<ref name="Volk_etal_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Volk|first1=Kathryn|last2=Gladman|first2=Brett|title=Consolidating and Crushing Exoplanets: Did It Happen Here?|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2015|volume=806|issue=2|page=L26|doi=10.1088/2041-8205/806/2/L26|arxiv=1502.06558|bibcode = 2015ApJ...806L..26V }}</ref> These explanations have their own potential problems, for example, the timing of the formation of the Borealis basin,<ref name="Andrews-Hanna_etal_2016">{{cite web|last1=Andrews-Hanna|first1=J. C.|last2=Bottke|first2=W. F.|title=The Post-Accretionary Doldrums on Mars: Constraints on the Pre-Noachian Impact Flux|url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2873.pdf|publisher=47th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference}}</ref> and whether objects should remain on orbits [[Vulcanoid|inside]] Mercury's.<ref name="Raymond_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Raymond|first1=Sean N.|last2=Izidoro|first2=Andre|last3=Bitsch|first3=Bertram|last4=Jacobsen|first4=Seth A.|title=Did Jupiter's core form in the innermost parts of the Sun's protoplanetary disc?|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2016|volume=458|issue=3|doi=10.1093/mnras/stw431|arxiv=1602.06573|url=http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/458/3/2962|pages=2962–2972|bibcode = 2016MNRAS.458.2962R }}</ref> A monotonically declining bombardment by planetesimals left over from the formation of the terrestrial planets has also been proposed. This hypothesis requires the lunar [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]] to have crystallized relatively late which may explain the differing concentrations of highly [[Goldschmidt classification#Siderophile elements|siderophile elements]] in the Earth and Moon.<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Morbidelli|first1=A.|last2=Nesvorny|first2=D.|last3=Laurenz|first3=V.|last4=Marchi|first4=S.|last5=Rubie|first5=D. C.|last6=Elkins-Tanton|first6=L.|last7=Jacobson|first7=S. A.|title=The Lunar Late Heavy Bombardment as a Tail-end of Planet Accretion|journal=Icarus|volume=305|pages=262–276|date=2018|arxiv=1801.03756|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103517303408|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2017.12.046|bibcode=2018Icar..305..262M}}</ref> A previous work, however, found that the most dynamically stable part of this population would become depleted due to its collisional evolution, making the formation of several or even the last two impact basins unlikely.<ref name=Bottke_etal_2007>{{cite journal|last=Bottke|first=Wiliam F.|author2=Levison, Harold F. |author3=Nesvorný, David |author4= Dones, Luke |title=Can planetesimals left over from terrestrial planet formation produce the lunar Late Heavy Bombardment?|journal=Icarus|date=2007|volume=190|issue=1|pages=203–223|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2007.02.010|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103507000966 |bibcode=2007Icar..190..203B}}</ref>
==Proposed names== According to Nesvorný, colleagues have suggested several names for the hypothetical fifth giant planet—[[Hades]], after the Greek god of the underworld; [[Liber]], after the Roman god of wine and a cognate of [[Dionysus]] and [[Bacchus]]; and [[Mefitis|Mephitis]], after the Roman goddess of toxic gases. Another suggestion is "Thing 1" from Dr. Seuss's ''[[Cat in the Hat]]'' children's book.<ref>A New Name for an Old Planet: ''New Scientist'': 01.10.2011: 15, https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn20952-missing-planet-explains-solar-systems-structure/</ref>
==Notes on Planet Nine== In January 2016, Batygin and Brown proposed that a distant massive [[Planet Nine|ninth planet]] is responsible for the alignment of the perihelia of several trans-Neptunian objects with semi-major axes greater than 250 AU.<ref name="TAJ201601" /> Although the mechanism for the ejection of the fifth giant planet in the five-planet Nice model is reminiscent of the origin of Planet Nine, with a gravitational instability including an encounter with Jupiter, it is unlikely to be the same planet. The estimated timing of the capture of Planet Nine onto its distant orbit, three to ten million years after the formation of the Solar System, when the Sun was still in its [[open cluster|birth cluster]], is inconsistent with a giant-planet instability that was responsible for the Late Heavy Bombardment.<ref name="Drake_2016">{{cite web|last1=Drake|first1=Nadia|title=How can we find planet nine? (and other burning questions)|url=http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2016/01/22/how-can-we-find-planet-nine-and-other-burning-questions/|website=No place like home|publisher=National Geographic|accessdate=30 January 2016|date=2016-01-22}}</ref> A nearby star close enough to aid in Planet Nine's capture would also result in the capture of the [[Oort cloud]] objects on orbits much closer than has been estimated from the orbits of comets.<ref name="Raymond_2016b">{{cite web|last1=Raymond|first1=Sean|title=Planet Nine: kicked out by the moody young Solar System?|url=http://planetplanet.net/2016/02/02/planet-nine-kicked-out-by-the-moody-young-solar-system/|website=PlanetPlanet|accessdate=27 February 2016|date=2016-02-02}}</ref> However, Batygin and Brown remarked that there is possibility of retaining the ejected giant due to interactions with the protoplanetary disk.<ref name="TAJ201601" /><ref name="Bromley_2014">{{Cite journal|last1=Bromley|first1=Benjamin|last2=Kenyon|first2=Scott|title=The fate of scattered planets|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=796|issue=2|pages=141|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/796/2/141|year=2014}}</ref> Also, in November 2017, Brown stated in a reply to a Twitter inquiry about the correlation between the five-planet Nice model and Planet Nine "i'd [sic] say it's a good chance that Planet Nine is Nice planet #5"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mobile.twitter.com/plutokiller/status/931675640658460672|title=Twitter|website=mobile.twitter.com|access-date=2017-11-26}}</ref>
